message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a possible diagnosis of Huntington's disease. The sudden jerky upper extremity movements and flat affect are characteristic of the disease. Further workup should include a head CT to look for dorsal striatum atrophy, which is a hallmark finding of Huntington's disease. Positive 14-3-3 CSF assay is seen in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, alpha-synuclein aggregates on brain biopsy are seen in Parkinson's disease, and neurofibrillary tangles on brain biopsy are seen in Alzheimer's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest Huntington’s disease, which is characterized by atrophy of the striatum in the brain. Therefore, the correct answer is (D). Positive 14-3-3 CSF assay is seen in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, Alpha-synuclein aggregates on brain biopsy is seen in Parkinson’s disease, and neurofibrillary tangles on brain biopsy is seen in Alzheimer’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of Huntington’s disease, which is characterized by atrophy of the dorsal striatum. While other options may be seen in other neurodegenerative diseases, dorsal striatum atrophy is specific to Huntington’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest possible Huntington's disease, which is characterized by atrophy of the dorsal striatum, leading to involuntary movements and cognitive decline. Thus, the most likely finding on further workup would be dorsal striatum atrophy on head CT. Positive 14-3-3 CSF assay is seen in some cases of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, alpha-synuclein aggregates on brain biopsy is seen in Parkinson’s disease, and neurofibrillary tangles on brain biopsy are seen in Alzheimer’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of depression and strange movements, along with his occupation and hypertension, suggest the possibility of Huntington’s disease. On further workup, dorsal striatum atrophy may be seen on head CT. The other options relate to other neurodegenerative disorders such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (positive 14-3-3 CSF assay), Parkinson’s disease (alpha-synuclein aggregates on brain biopsy), and Alzheimer’s disease (neurofibrillary tangles on brain biopsy).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of depression, strange movements, and flat affect with facial grimace and sudden jerky movements of his upper extremities suggest Huntington's disease. This disease causes atrophy of the dorsal striatum, so the answer is (D). 14-3-3 CSF assay is used for diagnosis of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, Alpha-synuclein aggregates are seen in Parkinson’s disease, and Neurofibrillary tangles are seen in Alzheimer’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Huntington’s disease, a neurodegenerative disorder that affects movement, cognition, and personality. The sudden jerky movements of his upper extremities are characteristic of chorea, and the flat affect with facial grimace suggests parkinsonism. On further workup, dorsal striatum atrophy is often seen on head CT in patients with Huntington’s disease. Positive 14-3-3 CSF assay is associated with prion disease, alpha-synuclein aggregates on brain biopsy are seen in Parkinson’s disease, and neurofibrillary tangles are seen in Alzheimer’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a possible diagnosis of Huntington's disease, which is characterized by atrophy of the dorsal striatum. A positive 14-3-3 CSF assay is associated with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, alpha-synuclein aggregates are seen in Parkinson's disease, and neurofibrillary tangles are associated with Alzheimer's disease, none of which match the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of depression and sudden jerky movements of the upper extremities, which suggests Huntington’s disease. Dorsal striatum atrophy is commonly seen on imaging studies in patients with Huntington’s disease. The other options are not commonly associated with Huntington’s disease: positive 14-3-3 CSF assay is seen in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, alpha-synuclein aggregates on brain biopsy are seen in Parkinson’s disease, and neurofibrillary tangles on brain biopsy are seen in Alzheimer’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms appear to match those of Huntington’s disease, which is characterized by an autosomal dominant genetic mutation causing atrophy of the dorsal striatum. Therefore, Dorsal striatum atrophy on head CT is most likely to be seen on further workup. Positive 14-3-3 CSF assay is seen in prion diseases and alpha-synuclein aggregates on brain biopsy are seen in Parkinson’s disease, while neurofibrillary tangles on brain biopsy are seen in Alzheimer’s disease.
